newsitem.title: USA: IMM currency futures close mostly higher.
newsitem.headline: IMM currency futures close mostly higher.

text.p: IMM currency futures closed mostly higher, with yen leading advances and marks holding slim gains in rangebound trade ahead of the European Union's Amsterdam summit, traders and floor analysts said.
"Marks will be relatively flat ahead of Amsterdam," one trader said.

September marks remained below Tuesday's highs as comments from various European officials failed to lift expectations for a budget stability pact at the June 16 meeting, they said. Expectations for a pact were dashed on Monday after France said it needed at least a week to consider the budget accord.
On Wednesday, French president Jacques Chirac said in response to reporters' questions that he believed a stability pact could be signed at the EU summit in Amsterdam.
German finance minister Theo Waigel said EU economics and finance ministers could gather for a special meeting on Sunday night ahead of Monday's summit.

However, September marks only rallied to $0.5879, below Tuesday's pit session high of $0.5887. Resistance is at the 50-day moving average of $0.5901 and at the one-week high of $0.5916. One trader estimated that September marks would rally no higher than $0.6001, or 1.6780 spot, in the near term.
"It seems as though EMU will be pushed through in a dilutive manner," one currency analyst said. "The mark will continue to have safe-haven status, but ultimately this is bearish."
He, as well as other currency analysts, said EMU uncertainties were supporting yen. Several noted the decline in the cash mark/yen spread.
"We will be watching mark/yen tonight," one currency futures trader said.
They said the dollar was bogged down by trade problems, and waning expectations for a U.S. rate hike in July.

They said U.S. May retail sales and producer prices could confirm the low U.S. inflationary environment. Retail sales, which will be released on Thursday at 0830 EDT/1230 GMT, are forecast to rise 0.4 percent, from down 0.3 percent in April.
Weekly U.S. jobless claims will also be released on Thursday. Claims are forecast to fall to 326,000, from 337,000 in the previous week.

The U.S. May Producer Price Index (PPI), which will be out on Friday at 0830 EDT/1230 GMT, is estimated to rise 0.1 percent overall and in the core rate. In April overall PPI fell 0.6 percent, while the core rate declined 0.1 percent.

At the end of pit trade, September yen was up $0.000100 at $0.009129, marks rose $0.0010 at $0.5870, Swiss francs were $0.0024 higher at $0.7041, sterling fell $0.0008 at $1.6342, Canadian dollars were unchanged at $0.7258, Australian dollars were $0.0050 lower at $0.7577 and Mexican pesos were $0.000425 higher at $0.120525.
